title: INVENTORY / CODEX URIK
description: An introductory race creation and dweorg cultural backstory manual available to purchase in the board game mountain.

dialogueTree.title: Codex Urik: "The title reads: "Codex Urik: the I..."
dialogueTree.text: The title reads: "Codex Urik: the Industrious Dweorgr of Wirr√¢l". It's an introductory race creation and dweorg cultural backstory manual.

links.title: Conceptualization: "Close your eyes. Reflect upon your..."
links.text: Close your eyes. Reflect upon your core essence -- *really* bore into the depths of your soul and reach a hand toward the book stand.

links.title: Codex Urik: "A stocky man on the cover art of th..."
links.text: A stocky man on the cover art of the codex looks straight at you. He is horrendously hairy with a bulbous nose. He wields a large battle axe and grins like a maniac.

links.title: Codex Urik: "The normal dweorgr are a breed inte..."
links.text: The normal dweorgr are a breed intelligent yet greedy who drink hard and do battle even harder. Yet behind the brutish exterior, they also enjoy braiding their hair and beard, and going on heroic quests. This latter activity is most common for shield dweorgr.

links.title: You: "I feel profound kinship with this m..."
links.text: I feel profound kinship with this man.

links.title: Conceptualization: "Embrace your inner dweorg. You're a..."
links.text: Embrace your inner dweorg. You're a tall dweorg. Become the Dweorg King.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Dweorgr, huh?" The lieutenant shru..."
links.text: "Dweorgr, huh?" The lieutenant shrugs. "I was always more of a sidhe or huldur guy myself."

links.title: You: "I'm not sure this is the correct ch..."
links.text: I'm not sure this is the correct choice.

links.title: Conceptualization: "Like a tiny homunculus, the dweorg..."
links.text: Like a tiny homunculus, the dweorg lives within your blue soul.

links.title: Conceptualization: "You see an old, out-of-shape drunka..."
links.text: You see an old, out-of-shape drunkard of a cop incapable of solving a simple case. Imaginary worlds can't save you.
